extendedIngredients.name: artichoke hearts
extendedIngredients.originalString: 2 cups artichoke hearts, halved or quartered

extendedIngredients.name: belgian endive
extendedIngredients.originalString: 2 heads Belgian endive, leaves separated and rinsed

recipes.title: Artichoke Heart and Quinoa Salad

winePairing.pairingText: Chardonnay, Gruener Veltliner, and Sauvignon Blanc are great choices for Salad. Sauvignon Blanc and Gruner Veltliner both have herby notes that complement salads with enough acid to match tart vinaigrettes, while a Chardonnay can be a good pick for creamy salad dressings. One wine you could try is Waterbrook Reserve Chardonnay. It has 5 out of 5 stars and a bottle costs about 20 dollars.

productMatches.title: Waterbrook Reserve Chardonnay
productMatches.description: Beautiful and golden in color, this chardonnay has persistent ripe pear and lychee flavors that are complemented by a subtle, sweet toasty oak. Very balanced acid harmonizes the thick viscosity of this ripe and decadent wine.

recipes.instructions: Wine SuggestionsSomewhat bitter-tasting foods, such as the Belgian endive, plus toasted nuts and the nutty flavor of artichokes combined with a mild-flavored cooked grain gussie up nicely with a flavorful vinaigrette or dressing. Such a dish pairs well with a fine-tasting Sauvignon Blanc. Try the Jean Reverdy Sancerre Vignoble de la Reine Blanche.

steps.step: Somewhat bitter-tasting foods, such as the Belgian endive, plus toasted nuts and the nutty flavor of artichokes combined with a mild-flavored cooked grain gussie up nicely with a flavorful vinaigrette or dressing. Such a dish pairs well with a fine-tasting Sauvignon Blanc. Try the Jean Reverdy Sancerre Vignoble de la Reine Blanche.
